awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Elucidating the Targets and Functions of Mammalian tRNA methyltransferase orthologs
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to understand how ribonucleic acid (RNA) molecules influence cell growth, development, and response to the environment. Current evidence shows that RNA function can be regulated by the presence of chemical groups (modifications) that are added to the RNA by specific enzymes. However, much remains to be learned about how the enzymes find their target RNAs, how the modifications change RNA functions, and how the modified RNAs regulate critical cellular processes. This research will address those questions, while providing a dynamic research environment to foster the scientific training and development of underrepresented groups in science such as minorities and women. To share new technical approaches developed during the research, students will produce video-based tutorials to serve as a teaching and training resource for the scientific community. The project will also provide educational workshops for underserved high school students to encourage curiosity and experimentation in the field of biology. 

Mammalian genomes are predicted to encode a diverse number of transfer RNA methyltransferase (Trm) enzymes, but the cellular functions for the majority of Trm proteins remain unknown. The following project aims to elucidate the biological roles of the numerous uncharacterized mammalian Trm enzymes by: 1) establishing the protein interaction networks of human Trm enzymes, 2) identifying the cellular targets of Trm proteins, and 3) determining the cellular processes modulated by Trm proteins. The goals will be achieved through an integrated biochemical, molecular and genetic approach involving proteomic analysis of Trm complexes together with global transcription and translation profiling of human cells with altered Trm proteins. Through these discoveries, the work promises to lay a foundation of new understanding of how the RNA modifications catalyzed by diverse Trm enzymes translate into physiological outputs that help cells respond to various environmental conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Transfer RNAs (tRNAs) are an important class of biological molecules required for the process of making proteins inside cells. Cellular tRNAs are modified through the addition of chemical groups by proteins called tRNA modification enzymes. Mammalian cells are predicted to make many different types of tRNA modification enzymes, but the targets and functions for these tRNA modification enzymes have been unknown. Through the research funded by this Award, we have generated a protein-RNA interaction map that has revealed unexpected substrates and partners of mammalian tRNA modification enzymes. This map has allowed us to elucidate the molecular mechanisms into how tRNA modification enzymes find their RNAs, how modifications change RNA structure, and how modified RNAs regulate critical cellular processes. These findings are important by defining the roles of mammalian tRNA modification enzymes in tRNA folding, stability, and function. Notably, these discoveries reveal how chemical changes in tRNA can influence cell growth, neurodevelopment, and response to the environment. This research has also deciphered the molecular effects associated with genetic variants in human tRNA modification enzymes. Finally, the project has yielded new research tools and approaches for detecting RNA modifications in different organisms that will be valuable resources for the scientific field. In terms of intellectual merit, the outcomes from this research provide a blueprint for understanding the biological and evolutionary basis for diversification of tRNA modification enzymes in mammals, including novel mechanisms of gene regulation. In total, the findings from this project have resulted in 11 research articles, 1 review article, and 2 book Chapters.

In terms of broader impacts, this project has yielded a series of video-based laboratory protocols that incorporate an innovative first-person point of view for the classroom and research setting. This library of video methods serves as a teaching and training resource for the scientific community and is publicly available online. In the classroom setting, we have designed and shared discussion-based workshops led by near-peers that highlight the emerging role of RNA biology. In addition, the activities in this project have provided summer-term science programming for more than 200 high school students in the Rochester City School District via the Upward Bound Science and Math Program. These hands-on experiences provide a research environment for high school students in underserved Rochester communities to learn modern scientific techniques and experiments.
